loans.name: Rahmatullo

texts.en:
Rahmatullo is a generous man. He was born in the northern part of Tajikistan in 1973. He is living in a rural area with his family. He is married and has four children. 

For more than 15 years, he has been busy in agriculture. He plants vegetables and cereals. He says that it is a pleasure to work in the land; he enjoys each moment providing care for his plantings. Each year he fertilizes and cultivates a plot of land in order to reap a good harvest. He feeds and provides for his family with income that he earns from his agriculture. He asked for help from IMON to get a loan and to buy fertilizer and seeds. He hopes to be supported by Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Angelino

texts.en:
Angelino lives at Amulung. He is 47 years old, married and has two children. His wife is a teacher. 

To gain income, Angelino manages a printing and photography business. He hopes to make better sales for his small business through the good and satisfying services he offers. 

Now, Angelino is asking for 10,000 PHP to buy ink, papers and films for use in his business. With this additional capital, he will be able to buy necessary supplies needed to improve his business. Someday, he hopes to achieve a better income for his family's welfare.

loans.use: to buy ink, papers and films for use in his printing and photography business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Increase the stock in her store

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
Marjorie is a woman and she is 22 years old now.

Marjorie has a buy and sell coconut business in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more coconut to sell.

Marjorie has been in this business for 4 years. In the future, Marjorie would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more coconuts to sell

loans.name: Ajai

texts.en:
Ajai is 45 years old and lives together with his 3 school going children. He works in a banana company as a field worker. 

For an extra income, Ajai grows broiler chickens for sale. He has a potentially big market, because he delivers the most of the chickens at work and also sells in the neighborhood.  

Ajai wants to extend this, so he can sell more and can save for his family future. He needs SRD 2.000 for the purchase of chickens and feed for them.

loans.use: To purchase chickens and feed for them, to improve the future of his family

loans.name: Sani

texts.en:
Sani is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Bamiyayi Village. He joined Babban Gona to expand his farm and grow his agricultural business. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, he will have access to the best farm inputs in the market such as fertilizers, herbicides, and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize per hectare, double the Nigerian national average of 14 bags. 

This will see him increase his household income considerably. Thanks to Babban Gona's support, Sani now has the opportunity to increase his yields and income and use his extra earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to purchase improved farm inputs that will increase his farm yields.

loans.name: Sefa

texts.en:
Sefa is married and a mother of two. She worked in private companies for years and she quit. She learned how to make scarves and started selling. Sefa heard that one of her friends had purchased fabric for her scarves with the help of a microcredit. With her first loan she bought fabric for her scarves and increased her sales. With the help of her second loan she is planning to again buy more fabric for her scarves and to increase her sales thus making contributions to the family budget.
Translated from Turkish by Maya staff.

Sefa hanım evli iki çocuk annesi. Uzun yıllar özel şirketlerde çalışmış Ve işten ayrılmış. Şal yapmayı öğrenerek satışlar yapmaya başlamış. Şal ipi almak için mikro krediyi bir arkadaşından duymuş ve mikro kredi kullanmış. Kullandığı mikro kredi ile şal ipi alarak üretmiş ve satışlarını artırmış. İkinci kredi ile de şal ipi alarak üretip satışlarını artırmak ve aile ekonomisine katkı sağlamak istiyor.

loans.use: to buy the necessary wool to make her scarves.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is a married woman with six children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She is 49 years old and has two children who are in school. She has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

Jocelyn has requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional fishing materials. She has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, Jocelyn would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional fishing materials.

loans.name: Lizcel

texts.en:
Lizcel is 36 years old and married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, soap, milk, sugar, groceries, etc.

Lizcel has borrowed and repaid 12 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from buying and selling vegetables. She aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, soap, milk, sugar, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Lorilyn

texts.en:
Lorilyn works hard to support her family.  She is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional boxes of fish to sell.

Lorilyn has been in this business for five years now. She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of fish to sell.

loans.name: Maribeth

texts.en:
Maribeth is 36 years old and married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell like coffee, canned goods, chips, etc.

Maribeth has been in this business for five years and has previously received funds through Kiva. Maribeth aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like coffee, canned goods, chips, etc.

loans.name: Flor De Alba

texts.es:
Flor tiene 32 años y está divorciada. Es madre de dos niños, a quienes mantiene desde hace seis años. Desde que era pequeña, su sueño siempre fue hacer un mundo más feliz y ayudar a las personas. Es por eso que Flor es enfermera y trabaja en un hospital dando terapia física. 
Ella combinó su perseverancia y el deseo de ganar los mayores ingresos posibles y abrió un pequeño restaurante hace cinco años. Ella vende desayunos y todo tipo de comida como licuados, sándwiches, pasteles, galletas y fruta. Con un préstamo de MXN 10,000 ella comprará leche, pan, cereales, azúcar y huevos para preparar la mejor comida de la región y también adquirir una pequeña estufa nueva. 
Su mayor sueño es tener estabilidad financiera para poder ofrecerles las mejores condiciones de vida y educación a sus hijos. Quiere que sus hijos salgan adelante y estén orgullosos de ella y de todo lo que ha hecho. Flor es una mujer segura, trabajadora y ha luchado mucho por estar en donde se encuentra el día de hoy. Está muy comprometida para estar a tiempo en las fechas de pago en su primer préstamo con Konfío.
texts.en:
Flor is 32 years old and is divorced. She is a mother of two kids, who she has had for 6 years. Since she was little, her dream has been to make the world happier and to help people. It's for this reason that Flor is a nurse and works in a hospital doing physical therapy.

She combined her perserverance and the dream of earning the highest earnings possible  and opened a small restaurant five years ago. She sells breakfast and all kinds of food such as drinks, sandwiches, pastries, cookies, and fruit. With a loan of MXN 10,000, she will buy milk, break, cereal, sugar, and eggs to prepare the best food in the region and also the get a new small stove.

Her greatest dream is to have financial stability to be able to offer the best conditions of life and education to her children. She wants her children to go forward and be proud of her and everything that she has done. Flor is sure, a hard worker, and has fought to be where she is today. She is confident that she will make her payments on time for her first loan with Konfio.

loans.use: to buy milk, bread, cereal, sugar, eggs, and a new small stove

loans.name: Jiguisseme  2 Group

texts.fr: Les membres du JIGUISSEME 2  sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  38 ans, 3 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à KADIANA, cercle de KOLONDIEBA, une des préfectures de la  3ème région administrative du Mali. Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. Elles sont à leur septième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. La spéculation cultivée est : l’arachide, le gombo et le mais avec MARIAM la personne au milieu sur la photo position debout. Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, la semence et payer les frais de labours pour exploiter : 2 hectares. La production est vendue à KADIANA après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 110 000F CFA qui la permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The members of the group JIGUISSEME 2 are married women, who average 8 years of age and three children each, all living in polygamous families in KADIANA, in Cercle de KOLONDIEBA, a prefecture in the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. The women are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their farm work during the rainy season. They are now on their 7th loan with the institution; the past loans have indeed been paid back.  

The crops grown are: peanuts, okra, and corn, as is the case with MARIAM, who is the person standing in the middle in the photo. With this loan, she intends to pay for farm inputs and seeds and to cover the cost of plowing for making use of:  2 hectares.

After the harvest, the produce is sold to men and women customers in KADIANA. She plans on making a profit of 110,000 francs CFA that will enable her to pay back the loan and also to help out her husband in covering day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to pay for farm inputs, seeds, and plowing

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with four children. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 22,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell like rice, sardines, shampoo, etc. 

She industriously earns additional income through other business ventures like motorcycle transport. She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.  Cecilia dreams that one day she will be able to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell like rice, sardines, shampoo, etc.

loans.name: Rosela

texts.en:
Rosela is 62 years old and married with six children. She works very hard to provide for them. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell like canned goods, soap, chips, bread, etc.

Rosela has been in this business for five years. In the future Rosela would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell like canned goods, soap, chips, bread, etc.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine, a 37-year-old married mother of two, has been farming coconuts for 10 years in the Philippines. She earns additional income from buying and selling rice grains.

Christine is borrowing PHP 10000 through NWTF to purchase additional fertilizers. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to  save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional fertilizers

loans.name: Roger

texts.en: Roger wants to thank you all the support in the previous loan, Roger obtained earnings with sale of solar lamps, and he wants to expand his business, buying more lamps to increase his sales and enhance his family´s economy. By sellilng these solar lamps,  Roger helps families in his community to have access to better lighting,  avoid using kerosene and candles, and also to save money by charging their cell phones with these solar lamps. He believes this is a way to protect the environment and the health of people.

loans.use: To buy more solar lamps to sell his customers

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 34 years old. He is married to Pacificah and he supports a family of four. 

For the past two years, Peter has run a motorcycle transport service and he earns KES 9,000  each month. 

Peter is requesting a KES 25,000  loan from VisionFund Kenya to purchase spare parts for his motorcycle and to pay for repairs and maintenance. This will be his first loan. 

He will use his loan to offer better and faster transportation services to clients. 

Peter plans to use the profit from his loan to repay his debt and expand his business. 

In the future, he hopes to be financially stable.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for his motorcycle and to pay for repairs and maintenance

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with five children. She runs a buy-and-sell charcoal business in the Philippines, and requested a 15,000 PHP  loan through NWTF to purchase more sacks of charcoal to sell.

Clarita industriously earns additional income through other business ventures like buying and selling rice and running a general store. She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she requested another loan to further build her businesses. 

Clarita dreams that one day she will be able to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is 66 years old, and married with six children. She works hard to provide for her family. 

Cristina runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell like spices, soap, shampoo, canned goods, etc. She borrowed and paid back 23 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for four years and also earns an income from food vending.

Cristina aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like spices, soap, shampoo, canned goods, etc.

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with three children. She runs a general store in the Philippines.

Dina requested a 13,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks like sardines, noodles, coffee, etc. to sell. She industriously earns additional income through other business ventures like fish vending.

Dina dreams that one day she will be able to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks like sardines, noodles, coffee, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Damiana Graciela

texts.es:
Damiana es una mujer de 53 años de edad, casada, tiene 3 hijos de 12, 16 y 18 años de edad, y su negocio es la producción de queso artesanal.
Ella es emprendedora, paciente, constante, de buena actitud, comprometida con su trabajo, responsable y muy trabajadora. Su trabajo lo desarrolla en la comunidad ‘Cohana’; que se encuentra en una península o archipiélago montañoso, rodeado por las aguas de la Bahía que corresponde a una planicie con vegetación de totorales y vegas inundadas, situada al sur del lago sagrado Titicaca a 3985 metros sobre el nivel del mar. 
Damiana es de tez morena, ojos pardos, cabello negro largo lo usa trenzado, baja estatura, complexión física mediana, viste de forma tradicional (sombrero, manta y pollera), su lengua materna es el Aymará que se habla en el lugar y habla español por cultura general y por el comercio que realiza. Su vida la comparte junto a su esposo que trabaja en agricultura, viven en una casa propia construida de adobe con techo de calamina que cuenta con energía eléctrica y agua de pozo extraída mediante bomba eléctrica. Su trabajo es la producción y venta de queso artesanal; elaborado con leche cruda de su propio establo, moldeado a mano, acomodado en envases hechos de totora. Actualmente se encuentra desarrollando nuevas variedades de queso como el queso con orégano, con picante, y otros, “trabajamos en la producción de queso desde todas nuestras vidas, queremos aumentar nuestras variedades…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que cuenta con una amplia experiencia familiar la desventaja es la falta de leche para la producción. Su sueño es ampliar su cantidad de ganado lechero y su producción de queso, ella desea realizar la compra de ganado lechero para aumentar su producción lechera y desarrollar nuevas variedades de queso. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 12 años que desarrolla esta actividad de forma independiente.
Es por esos motivos que Damiana solicita un préstamo para la compra de ganado lechero para aumentar su producción lechera y desarrollar nuevas variedades de quesos artesanales.
texts.en:
Damiana is a 53-year-old woman, married, who has 3 children who are 12, 16, and 18 years old. Her business is the production of handcrafted cheese.

She is entrepreneurial, patient, tenacious, with a good attitude, committed to her work, responsible, and very hard-working. She carries out her work in the community of ‘Cohana,’ which can be found on a peninsula or mountainous archipelago, surrounded by the waters of the bay that correspond to a plain with Totorales vegetation and flooded meadows, situated to the south of the sacred Lake Titicaca, at 3985 meters above sea level.

Damiana has dark skin, brown eyes, long black hair in a braid, is short in stature, with a medium physical build, dressed in traditional clothing (a hat, blanket, and skirt). Her mother tongue is Aymara, which is spoken in the area, and she speaks Spanish because of the general culture and the commerce that she performs. She shares her life with her husband, who works in agriculture. They live in their own home, constructed of adobe with a roof made of corrugated iron that has electricity and well-water extracted by an electric pump. 

Her work is the production and sale of handcrafted cheese, produced from raw milk from her own cowshed, molded by hand, and stored in containers made of large reeds. Currently, she finds herself developing new varieties of cheese such as cheese with oregano, spicy cheese, and others. “We have worked on the production of cheese all our lives; we want to increase our varieties,” she comments. 

The advantage of her business is that is has a lot of family experience; the disadvantage is the lack of milk production. Her dream is to increase her quantity of dairy cows and her production of cheese. She wishes to carry out the purchase of dairy cows to increase her milk production and develop new varieties of cheese. This is the first sequence of loans with the institutions in the 12 years that she has carried out this activity independently.

It is because of these reasons that Damiana is requesting a loan for the purchase of dairy cows to increase her milk production and to develop new varieties of handcrafted cheeses.

loans.use: to increase her dairy production and to develop new varieties of handcrafted cheese.

loans.name: Jean Mari Vianney

texts.en:
Jean Marie Vianey is 26 years old and is married. He is a farmer and he has been growing maize for the past 3 years.  His wife is a business woman. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to pay workers who harvested his maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay medical insurance.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested his maize.

loans.name: Annonciathe

texts.en:
Annonciathe is aged 65 years and is married with 5 children aged between 12 and 23 years. They go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 4 years. Also her husband is a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay the workers who harvested her maize. The profits from the business will be used to improve her welfare and pay school fees of her children. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested her maize.

loans.name: Madaleine

texts.en:
Madeline aged 27 years. She is married with 2 children aged between 1 and 5 years, who do not go to schooleyt. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 3 years. Also her husband is a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested their  maize. The profits from the business will be used to increase her welfare. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested her maize.

loans.name: Reina De La Paz

texts.es:
Reina de 29 años de edad, está estudiando 3° año de bachillerato, actualmente está acompañada y su pareja se dedica a la agricultura, tiene 3 hijos de los cuales solo dos están estudiando, además Reina vive con sus padres.

Reina se dedica a cocinar los alimentos para los alumnos de la escuela de su comunidad, ya tiene 6 años en esta actividad la cual aprendió de su madre.


Ella necesita el crédito para comprar 4 quintales de fórmula, 4 quintales de sulfato, una botella  de gramoxone, etc. Para el cultivo que realizará su esposo.

Ella sueña con aumentar la producción de cultivos y obtener buenas cosechas.
texts.en:
Reina is 29 years old, and is studying in her 3rd year of a bachelor's degree. She is currently married, and her husband works in agriculture. She has three children, and only two of them are in school. Also, Reina lives with her parents.

Reina earns a living cooking food for the students at her community school. She has been doing this for six years, and learned the occupation from her mother.

She is requesting a loan to buy four quintals of fertilizer, four quintals of sulfate, a bottle of herbicide, etc. for the farming work that her husband performs. She dreams that the farming production will increase and obtain good harvests.

loans.use: to buy four quintals of fertilizer, four quintals of sulfate, a bottle of herbicide, etc

loans.name: José Orlando

texts.es:
José de 48 años de edad, estudio únicamente 3° grado, se casó y su esposa vende antojitos en la comunidad y en la escuela, de él dependen sus padres, su esposa y sus tres hijos.
José se dedica a hacer viajes desde hace 5 años, oficio que realiza todos los días desde las 5:30 a.m. hasta horas de la tarde, hace viajes particulares y también a estudiantes que viajan de su comunidad hasta el pueblo donde se encuentra la escuela, también trabaja en ganadería en pequeña escala, pues tiene una vaca, dos toritos y una ternera, su esposa y sus hijos son quienes lo apoyan en el trabajo.
El crédito que está solicitando a CREDICAMPO le ayudará para comprar una vaca y para pagar alquiler del terreno donde cultiva.
Su sueño es comprar un camión grande para seguir haciendo viajes a la gente y apoyar a sus hijos en sus estudios.
texts.en: José is 48 years old and studied only up to Grade 3. He is married and his wife sells snack food in the community and in the school. His parents, wife and three children are dependent on him. José has worked driving for 5 years, work he does every day from 5:30 am until the afternoon. He makes individual trips as well as for students who travel from his community to the town where the school is located. He also works in raising cattle on a small scale as he has a cow, two calves and a heifer. His wife and children help him with this work. The loan he is requesting from Credicampo to help him buy a cow and to pay rent on the land he cultivates. His dream is to buy a large truck to continue transporting people and to support his children with their studies.

loans.use: to buy a cow and pay rent on the land that he cultivates.

loans.name: Ana Gloria

texts.es:
Ana de 33 años de edad, estudió hasta cuarto grado, está soltera y de ella solo dependen sus padres.

Ana se ha dedicado a la agricultura desde hace 30 años, realiza este trabajo debido a la necesidad de salir adelante,  ella se levanta a las cuatro de la mañana a organizar la casa y a preparar desayuno para sus padres, su primo le ayuda en el trabajo el cual está a 1 kilómetro de distancia.

Ella necesita el crédito para comprar insumos agrícolas y pagar mano de obra a su primo.

Ella sueña con tener una tienda con productos de la canasta básica y espera lograrlo con la ayuda de estos créditos.
texts.en: Ana is 33 years old and studied up to Grade 4. She is single and her parents depend on only her. Ana has worked in agriculture for 30 years. She does this work in order to get ahead. She gets up at 4 in the morning to organize the house and make breakfast for her parents. Her cousin helps her with the work which is one km away. She needs the loan to buy agricultural inputs and pay her cousin for labor. She dreams of having a store with basic food items and hopes to achieve this with the help of loans.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs and to pay her cousin for labor.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is 62 years old, and married with six children.  She works hard to provide for her family operating a general store in the Philippines.  She has been operating the general store for 2 years and earns additional income buying and selling rice.

Edith requested a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock of coffee, milk, and biscuits to sell.  She has borrowed and repaid 20 loans from NWTF prior to this loan.  

She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of coffee, milk, and biscuits to sell.

loans.name: Shahnoza

texts.ru: Шахнозе 22 года. Она из района Пяндж. Ее муж занимается животноводством. У нее имеется двое детей.  В течение многих лет Шахноза работает на земельном участке, сажает овощи и имеет хорошие возможности растениеводство. Работа на земле нелегкий труд, но она справляется со всеми обязательствами. Шахнозе нравиться  заниматься растениеводством, и нравиться когда она собирает богатый урожай. В таком возрасте  и такую молодую дехканку мало встречаешь. Она не смотря ни на что трудиться. В данный момент ей нужно минеральные удобрения для обработки землю. И она хочет взять кредит и приобрести минеральные удобрения.
texts.en: Shahnoza is 22 years old.  She comes from the Pyandj ditrict of Tajikistan.  Her husband raises livestock.  Shahnoza has two children.  For several years already, she has been cultivating a plot of land, growing vegetables and enjoying good farming conditions.  Working the land is not easy, but Shahnoza handles all aspects of her work very well.  She enjoys working in agriculture and she's particularly happy when she gets a good harvest.  You don't often meet farmers as young as Shahnoza.  However, in spite of her young age, she works very hard.  At the moment, she needs mineral fertilizers to prepare her land. She is taking a loan to make this purchase.

loans.use: to buy mineral fertilizers.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira works hard to support her family.  She is married and for 10 years has operated a furniture making business in the Philippines.

Elvira requested a 26,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional materials needed for her furniture business.

In the future, Elvira would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials needed for her furniture business.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is 55 years old and married with nine children, two of whom are in school. Evangeline works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 10,000 Philippines Peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock like bread, chips, soft drinks, sardines, and other items to sell.

Evangeline has been in this business for 30 years. She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock like bread, chips, soft drinks, sardines, and other items to sell

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma is 39 years old and married.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 17,000 Philippines Peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy additional stock of household goods to sell.

Gemma has borrowed and paid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for seven years and also earns an income from fish vending.

She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stock of household goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: This loan of $10,000 will help Zamgoat increase its sales, providing additional processing equipment, including a refrigerated display case.

loans.name: Genevieve

texts.en:
Genevieve works hard to support her family. Genevieve is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

She requested a 20,000 Philippines Peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell.

Genevieve has been in this business for 18 years now. In the future, Genevieve would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell

loans.name: Klara

texts.ru: Клара, 29 лет, не замужем, детей нет. У нее высшее образование, работает преподавателем в университете уже 4 года. Ее заработная плата - 10,275 сом (KGS) в месяц. Клара обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 147,000 сом (KGS) на проведение ремонта в доме. На полученные средства она приобретет экологичные пластиковые окна и двери, гипсокартон для утепления дома, обновит ванную комнату. Свои доходы Клара планирует и дальше вкладывать в улучшение жилищных условий.
texts.en: Klara is 29 years old, single, with no children.  She has a higher education and she has been working as a college professor for four years already.  She receives a monthly salary of 10,275 som (KGS).  She has turned to Bai Tushum Bank CJSC and requested a loan of 147,000 som (KGS) to perform some repairs at home.  She will use her loan to purchase environmentally-friendly plastic doors and windows and plasterboard for insulation.  She will also renovate her bathroom.  She is planning to use her income to further improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy environmentally friendly plastic windows and doors, plasterboard for insulation and other materials to renovate her house.

loans.name: Gerarda

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Gerarda works hard to support her family.

She has a tailoring shop business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from food vending and selling native products. Gerarda is borrowing 40,000 Philippines Pesos (PHP) through NWTF to purchase additional fabrics, threads, needles and other materials needed for her tailoring shop business.

Gerarda has been sustaining her business activities through her past two loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics, threads, needles and other materials needed

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is married with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Grace is 42 years old and has four children who are in school.

She has a buy and sell rice business in the Philippines. Grace requested a 14,000 Philippines Peso (PHP) loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell.

Grace has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, Grace would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat in order to work with security and stability in production

loans.name: Lorejoy

texts.en:
Lorejoy, 25, is working as a Finisher Packer at a garment factory in GMA, Cavite.  She has done this work for almost five years. She is responsible for tagging, packing, and sometimes the shipping of clothes and garments. 

Lorejoy is still single, but her responsibilities in the family cannot be discounted. In the Philippines, where families are known to be so closely knit, single persons are expected to help in their family’s expenses, from basic needs such as food, utilities, siblings’ education, parent’s medicines, and sometimes house construction or repair. 

Lorejoy’s ancestral house in the province has been wearing away due to frequent typhoons in the Philippines. She cannot save enough money for the needed housing repairs because low-income earners like her can hardly make both ends meet. She does not have access to banks and other financial institutions. This is the reason why she is prone to be victimized by money-lenders who charge very high interest rates and capture automated teller machine (ATM) cards as loan collateral. 

Lorejoy is thankful that she has other options as a member of CCT Covenant Community Service Cooperative*. She is looking forward to your help so that she can help provide the needed housing repairs and improvement. This is very important, so their house would be strong enough for the next typhoon that will visit the Philippines.  

As a responsible and loving daughter, Lorejoy desires to make her family happy at all times, uplift them from poverty, own a decent house and start a small business in the future. Of course she also dreams for herself a responsible husband and eventually a happy family of her own. 

She meets up with her co-fellowship** members to share stories of her work. 

*The Covenant Community Service Cooperative works to provide local communities with a labor force trained and equipped with the skills required for employment in construction and site development projects. The cooperative prepares its members to acquire these skills, qualify for jobs, cultivate savings consciousness, and provide decent shelter, food, and education for their families. Its core programs are the following: Professional Staff Services Program, Workers Guild Development Program, Enterprise Development Program, and Consultancy Services. 

**CCT staff and volunteers regularly conduct fellowship meetings for the factory workers before they start their daily work routines. Bible readings, prayer devotions, and spiritual mentoring and discipleship sessions take place during pre- and post-working hours and breaks, powering up the lives of both volunteer leaders and line workers.

loans.use: to pay for housing repairs and improvement.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 42 years old and married with four children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock like rice, sugar, sardines, etc. to sell.

Helen has borrowed and repaid 1 loan from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 20 years and also earns an income from farming sugarcane.

Helen aspires to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock for her general store.

loans.name: Nemecia

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal YANAHUARA SEÑOR DE TORRECHAYOC, el banco está ubicado en la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco.
La socia Nemecia alterna sus actividades diarias dedicándose al negocio de  venta de productos secos, la socia se siente agradecida por el  crédito y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas, la socia es una persona responsable y empeñosa, la socia vende  su mercadería a  todos sus clientes que le solicitan, siendo de esta manera que la socia saca adelante a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de maíz, trigo entre otros.
texts.en:
This borrower is a member of the communal bank "YANAHUARA SEÑOR DE TORRECHAYOC."  This group is from the province of Urubamba in the department of Cusco.

Nemecia, a member of this group, alternates her daily activities with her business selling dry goods.  She is grateful for this loan, and she promises to comply with the payment terms.  Nemecia is a responsible and hardworking person.  She sells her merchandise to all of the customers who request her goods,as this is the way that she supports her family.

Nemecia is requesting a loan to buy corn, wheat, and other products.

loans.use: to buy corn, wheat, and other products to sell

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita, 37 years old, is a minimum wage earner in a garment factory in GMA, Cavite.  She has been working there for thirteen long years that proves her patience and dedication to work.  As a Roving Quality Controller, she is responsible for inspecting the quality of products as well as supervising some levels of the workforce.  She also completes the delicate task of recording products and items.  It’s challenging for her to supervise some disobedient co-workers but she can manage them efficiently. 

Perlita is still single but her responsibilities in the family cannot be discounted.  In the Philippines where families are known to be so closely knit, single persons are expected to help in their family’s expenses, from basic needs such as food, utilities, sibling education, parent’s medicines, and sometimes house construction or repair.  Perlita’s ancestral house has been wearing away due to frequent visits of typhoons in the Philippines.  She cannot save enough money for house repairs because low-income earners like her can hardly make ends meat.  She has no access to banks and other financial institutions.  This is the reason why she is prone to be victimized by usurious money-lenders who charge very high interest rates and capture automated teller machine (ATM) cards as loan collateral.  Perlita is thankful that she has other options being a member of CCT Covenant Community Service Cooperative*.  She is very much looking forward to your help so she can help provide for needed house repairs and improvements.  This is very important so their house can be strong enough for the next typhoon to hit the Philippines.  

As a responsible and loving daughter, Perlita desires to make her family happy at all times, uplift them from poverty, own a decent house, and start a small business in the future.  Of course she also dreams of having a responsible husband and eventually a happy family of her own.  She meets up with her co-fellowship** members to share stories of her work. 

*The Covenant Community Service Cooperative works to provide local communities with a labor force trained and equipped with the skills required for employment. The cooperative prepares its members to acquire these skills, qualify for jobs, cultivate savings consciousness, and provide decent shelter, food, and education for their families. Its core programs are the following: Professional Staff Services Program, Workers Guild Development Program, Enterprise Development Program, and Consultancy Services. 

**CCT staff and volunteers regularly conduct fellowship meetings for the factory workers before they start their daily work routines.  Bible readings, prayer devotions, and spiritual mentoring and discipleship sessions take place during pre- and post-working hours and breaks, powering up the lives of both volunteer leaders and line workers.

loans.use: to pay for home repair and improvement.

loans.name: Sonia Marina

texts.es:
Sonia de 44 años de edad, estudió solamente 1° grado en la escuela para adultos mayores, actualmente está casada y tiene 7 hijos, dos viven en casa pero solo uno depende de ella.

Sonia se dedica a los oficios domésticos y al cuidado de los animales de corral, actividad que aprendió de su madre cuando tenía 14 años de edad, además uno de sus hijos que vive en USA es quien le ayuda económicamente a Sonia siempre que puede.

Ella solicita este crédito para comprar 4 terneras y 2 cerdos para comercializarlos posteriormente.

Su sueño es seguir trabajando para mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y también desea seguir comprando ganado.
texts.en:
Sonia is 44 years old, and she only studied up to 1st grade in a school for adults. She is now married and has 7 children, of which 2 live in the house but only one of them is her dependent. 

Sonia works in domestic work and in raising animals in the farmyard, a business that she learned from her mother when she was 14 years old. In addition, one of her children that lives in the USA helps her economically whenever he/she can.  

She is applying for this loan to purchase 4 veals and 2 pigs for selling them afterwards. 

Her dream is to continue working to improve the living conditions of her family and also to keep purchasing livestock.

loans.use: to purchase 4 veals and 2 pigs and sell them afterwards

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
Beverly is 60 years old, married and has six children.  

She is in the agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines. Beverly requested a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Beverly has been raising pigs for five years now and has borrowed four times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Suzette

texts.en:
Suzette is 51 years old, married and a hardworking female entrepreneur.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell such as canned goods, personal care products, etc.

She industriously earns additional income through other business ventures such as raising pigs.

Suzette dreams that one day she will be able to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell such as canned goods, personal care products, etc.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann, 29, is from Silang, Cavite. She has been employed as a Packer in a garment factory in GMA, Cavite for five years now. She’s responsible for folding, tagging, packing, and sometimes shipping clothes and garments. Sometimes her job requires her to remain standing throughout the whole duration of her shift, and normally she finds it difficult. But hardworking as she is, she willingly does it. 

She is earning a minimum wage just like her husband, Ranier, who is also a factory worker. They are blessed with a child who is elementary school. Like other minimum wage earners, Mary Ann’s dilemma is how to make both ends meet. Also at this stage, some of her siblings still seek financial help from her. 

Recently, her sister requested tuition fee support from her. Sadly, she has no available money but she doesn’t want to ignore her sister’s request. This is why Mary Ann asks for your support to help her with this problem. She hopes you would be one of God’s instruments to lighten her burden.  

Mary Ann dreams of having an abundant life someday, especially for their child. She trusts the Lord that their child will finish their education and gain a decent living wage someday.

Mary Ann meets up with her co-fellowship** members to share stories of her work. 

*The Covenant Community Service Cooperative works to provide local communities with a labor force trained and equipped with the skills required for employment in construction and site development projects. The cooperative prepares its members to acquire these skills, qualify for jobs, cultivate savings consciousness, and provide decent shelter, food, and education for their families. Its core programs are the following: Professional Staff Services Program, Workers Guild Development Program, Enterprise Development Program, and Consultancy Services. 

**CCT staff and volunteers regularly conduct fellowship meetings for the factory workers before they start their daily work routines. Bible readings, prayer devotions, and spiritual mentoring and discipleship sessions take place during pre- and post-working hours and breaks, powering up the lives of both volunteer leaders and line workers.

loans.use: to help provide for her sister's educational needs.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine is from Carmona, Cavite and has been employed as Packer in a garment factory in GMA, Cavite for eleven years now. She puts on tags, folds the finished clothing, and performs other tasks requested of her. 

She’s married to Rodrigo, also a factory worker, and they have two children. Geraldine’s minimum wage combined with her husband’s income cannot support their growing financial needs. Their income usually goes to basic needs such as food and utilities, and they struggle when it comes to their children’s education. 

There was a time when she borrowed money from a loan shark, who charged her very high interest rates and captured her automated teller machine (ATM) card as loan collateral. The high interest rate further depleted her budget for their everyday needs, that’s why she’s been longing to pay the balance of her debt and eventually recover her ATM card. 

She’s a member of CCT Covenant Community Service Cooperative* where she gained the inspiration to save and acquired more skills in budgeting. She is very much looking forward to your help so she can pay her debt, start anew, and save efficiently so she can better help her family.

Geraldine dreams of owning a house for her family someday. She also aspires that her children will finish their education as it is their most valued inheritance. 

She meets up with her co-fellowship** members to share stories of her life and work. 

*The Covenant Community Service Cooperative works to provide local communities with a labor force trained and equipped with the skills required for employment in construction and site development projects. The cooperative prepares its members to acquire these skills, qualify for jobs, cultivate savings consciousness, and provide decent shelter, food, and education for their families. Its core programs are the following: Professional Staff Services Program, Workers Guild Development Program, Enterprise Development Program, and Consultancy Services. 

**CCT staff and volunteers regularly conduct fellowship meetings for the factory workers before they start their daily work routines. Bible readings, prayer devotions, and spiritual mentoring and discipleship sessions take place during pre- and post-working hours and breaks, powering up the lives of both volunteer leaders and line workers.

loans.use: to pay her debt and recover her ATM card.

loans.name: Leden

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Leden works hard to support her family.

She has a business buying and selling tobacco in the Philippines, and she also earns additional income from a general store. Leden is borrowing PHP 17,000 through NWTF in order to purchase additional tobacco to resell.

Leden has been sustaining her business activities through her past 8 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase tobacco to resell.

loans.name: Alondra

texts.en: Alondra is the proud owner of a home-based daycare service in the Bronx. Inspired by experience with her own seven-year-old daughter, her daycare has been in business for five years. She loves working with kids and enjoys the independence of owning her business. After the slower winter months, recent better weather has helped her business pick up and she hopes to use this loan to increase the daycare’s quality and potential with more dolls, computers, desks, and paintings. She is a confident child specialist, verified by parents’ continued satisfaction. She envisions her daycare expanded in the future, and with more employees, she will ensure secure attention to all the children that need infant care. Alondra is planning to continue her own schooling, committed to furthering her daycare and her knowledge about the service.

loans.use: to expand her daycare by purchasing more furniture, computers, desks, and paint

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is thankful for your previous support that went a long way and paid for their tricycle's expenses. She and her husband, Isidro, are still working hard to pay for the tricycle in monthly installments. 

Sometimes, her husband’s income from driving the tricycle cannot suffice to pay the monthly installment fee, and Juliet is forced to earn additional income. During these times, Juliet remains strong to avoid the lure of usurious money-lenders because she has found another option through you. Again, she is hoping for your financial support.

This loan will be used partly for their tricycle’s monthly installment, and also to help support her mother’s transportation expenses to the province. 

Juliet aspires that their children will finish college as it is their most valued inheritance. With a college degree, they have a better chance to enjoy better living conditions. 

She continuously meets up with her co-fellowship members at CCT Covenant Community Service Cooperative to share stories of her life and work, draw inspiration from each other, and strengthen their spiritual and devotional life.

loans.use: to pay for tricycle and transportation expenses.

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan has always dreamed of owning his own fire inspection agency. He has been working in the fire safety field since he was 18 years old. He has worked in different areas of the industry, but he found his niche in inspections and maintenance. 
 
Over the last five years, Jonathan has seen a lot of these companies perform these inspections incorrectly. Since safety is of the utmost priority to Jonathan, he knew that he wanted to own his own company that operated with the highest standards. He formed Caliber Fire Protection earlier this year to educate people about fire inspection safety and perform inspections.
 
Jonathan will use his Kiva loan to cover startup costs including insurance fees and costs associated with printing marketing materials. 

He would love for his business to be successful enough so he can hire employees. This is an area of the industry that is thriving, so Jonathan feels confident with his connections that he will be able to build this business from the ground up.
   
“I am very excited to be a business owner,” stated Jonathan. “I have spent my entire career making connections and learning the in-and-outs of the fire inspection industry, so I am looking forward to putting my knowledge to use.”

loans.use: to cover startup costs including insurance fees and costs associated with printing marketing materials.

loans.name: Shawn

texts.en:
Veteran Shawn started Ducket’s Dollar Store with his wife last year.  Prior to owning his business, Shawn was a contractor with the military for 10 years working in Kuwait and Iraq.  During his time as a contractor, he became unable to work, so he decided to create a way for him and his family to earn an income.

Father of one, Shawn knew he always wanted to own a retail store. He noticed the retail industry trends and how successful dollar stores have been in recent years, so he decided to open his own dollar store. He differentiates his dollar store from others by providing quality products, affordable prices and excellent customer service. 

The business opened its doors six months ago. He has faced some challenges with a hard-to-find location, but he has been actively marketing the business and has a five-star rating on Yelp. 

Shawn will use his Kiva loan for working capital and to purchase inventory for the store. 

Shawn has a knack for the customer service and he has dreams of expanding Ducket’s Dollar Store nationwide. He hopes one day that his one-year-old son will be able to take over the business, so that it will be in the family for years to come.

loans.use: to have working capital and to purchase inventory for the store.

loans.name: Jakeline

texts.en:
Jacky has a passion for helping people. As a single mother of three children, Jacky wanted to start her own business so that she could be her own boss and spend more time with her children, while being able to provide a living for her family. 

In spring 2014, Jacky enrolled in the eight-week Accion Academy business training class, where she received hands-on training accompanied by one-on-one business counseling to give people the tools to start their own businesses. She completed the class successfully, with a plan of how she was going to launch her business.
  
After graduation, she was well equipped to start her business, Conexion California. Located in San Ysidro, Conexion California provides professional services in automotive, life, and health insurance.  She also offers live scan fingerprints, notary services, translation and document preparation services.
  
Jacky noticed that there are many similar businesses of this type, and very few deliver what they promise.  They are quick to charge a very expensive rate for their services, but are very slow to give results.
    
“I enjoy working on a personal level with my customers, where I get to be a part of their most important decisions of their life be it Insurance for their loved ones, or immigration for their new spouse, or just looking out for their best interest in filing taxes,” said Jacky. 

Jacky will use her Kiva loan to pay for insurance certifications and also to purchase a live scan fingerprint mobile machine.

Her goal is to provide quality and professional services with accurate results in all the important decisions in your life.

loans.use: to pay for insurance certifications and to purchase a live scan fingerprint mobile machine.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a butcher shop business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 1 year. Marilou earns additional income from buying and selling rice.

She is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF in order to purchase a whole pig for her butcher shop business.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase a whole pig for her business.

loans.name: Savoi

texts.en:
Three years ago, Savoi began mentoring under a successful mortgage broker. He had always been interested in entering the real estate industry, and felt with the mentorship opportunity, it was the right time to do so. 

With his background in sales, Savoi found it easy to make connections in the real estate industry. He received his real estate and lenders license, so he could begin selling homes and receiving commission for his sales. Savoi is very well educated; he has a degree from Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles, California.  He also has expertise in home loans, commercial loans, and refis. 

He is currently looking to grow his business and gain more awareness of his services through the development of a new website.  The creation of a website will help establish him as a real estate agent and loan officer, and as a reputable person in the industry, in preparation for future expansion.  His website will focus on the lending aspect of Savoi's work, spotlighting referrals and real estate agents, and highlighting properties that are less known in the community. 

His hope is to expand his business to include public speaking and education, with publication of books explaining the real estate industry. With Savoi’s drive and dedication, he will be able live his dream of owning his own business.

loans.use: to develop a new website.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
This woman's name is Lolita - 53, resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Ponciano, a security guard, and she is a mother to her children who have their own respective families already. She manages their household while operating the business to augment their income and meet their everyday expenses.

Lolita has an ornamental plant business. She grows garden plants that are native to the Philippines like ylang-ylang, golden shower and dahlias, and also a variety of hanging plants and other similar plants. Her regular customers are local tourists, neighbors and the nearby community. She earns a minimum of PHP 3,000 in sales every week.

To help her expand her farm, she is requesting a PHP 25,000 loan which she will use to buy fertilizer and various kinds of garden seedlings, pots and nets to grow healthier ornamental plants. She thanks God for her healthy and beautiful ornamental plants and the financial help that will be given to her, for it will surely help to provide for their daily needs. 

Lolita's dream is for her ornamental business to flourish. She prays that God will grant her and her family good health and long life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members*  to share stories of her work every week, and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

 * All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for pots, wires, net, fertilizer, and ornamental seedlings.

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion works hard to support her family. She is widowed and has a buy and sell of herbal products business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more bottles of herbal products to sell.

Salvacion has been in this business for three years now.

In the future, Salvacion would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her grandchildren to college.

loans.use: to purchase more bottles of herbal products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fonio cereal for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a 40-year-old factory worker who is married to Daisy, 40, who is a housewife and runs a “sari-sari” store (variety store). They are living in San Pedro, Laguna with their only child. 

Everyday, Joseph travels to GMA, Cavite to work as a presser in a garment factory. For three years now, he does the pressing, folding and packaging of finished clothing. Sometimes, he finds difficulty in the long hours of pressing clothes, but nonetheless, he is happy with his work. 

Joseph and Daisy are already preparing for the growing financial demands in raising their child. He wants to have additional income by procuring more items for sale in their variety store. Particularly, he wants to add perfume and cologne because he noticed that it’s in demand nowadays. He’s confident that he can efficiently manage that kind of business with the help of his supportive wife. 

He fervently prays that through your help, he can obtain additional capital for their business. As a member of CCT Covenant Community Service Cooperative*, he won’t have any problem in repaying the loan because it will be deducted from his salary every pay day.
 
It is his dream that their only child will finish college because it is the most valued inheritance that they can give to their child. He also desires to have a vehicle someday that he can use for his business. 

Joseph meets up with his co-fellowship** members to share stories of his life and work. 

*The Covenant Community Service Cooperative works to provide local communities with a labor force trained and equipped with the skills required for employment. The cooperative prepares its members to acquire these skills, qualify for jobs, cultivate savings consciousness, and provide decent shelter, food, and education for their families. Its core programs are the following: Professional Staff Services Program, Workers Guild Development Program, Enterprise Development Program, and Consultancy Services. 

**CCT staff and volunteers regularly conduct fellowship meetings for the factory workers before they start their daily work routines. Bible readings, prayer devotions, and spiritual mentoring and discipleship sessions take place during pre- and post-working hours and breaks, powering up the lives of both volunteer leaders and line workers.

loans.use: to add capital to their retail business particularly perfume

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy millet grains for sale.

loans.name: Nelita

texts.en:
This woman's name is Nelita, and she is 52 and a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Eleuterio, a teacher, and they have four children, of whom one is in college, two are in high school, and the other one is already working. She manages her household while operating the business. She works hard to augment their income, to meet their daily personal and household needs, and to send her three children to school. 

Nelita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a general store is basically a small convenience store which sells fresh, dry and packaged commodities directly to consumers. Almost all products are essential household items and food. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by buying supplies at wholesale prices and then selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum net income of PHP 800 a day. 

To help her continue operations of her general store business, she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan which she will use to buy grocery items such as fresh meat, sacks of rice, charcoal, soda and other grocery stuff. She is positive that it will boost her income as she expands her business. Her earnings are their source of income to meet their daily expenses and to send her children to school. She thanks God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given to her.

Nelita trusts that God will help her store to prosper so she can send all her children to college. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, beverages and other toiletries to sell.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
As a single parent of five children, Marites works hard to support her family. She has a vegetable vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending.  

Marites is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF in order to purchase additional vegetables to resell.

Marites has been sustaining her business activities through her past 3 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so that she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Mary works hard to support her family.

She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending. Mary is borrowing PHP 22,000 through NWTF in order to buy additional boxes of fish to resell at her fish vending business.

Mary has been sustaining her business activities through her past 5 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so that she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of fish to sell.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Virginia works hard to support her family.

She has a restaurant business in the Philippines and earns additional income from her general store. Virginia is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business like meat, vegetables, eggs, etc. for her restaurant business.

Virginia has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream:  to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business like meat, vegetables, and eggs

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fonio cereal for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fonio cereal and milk for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
Rosie is 58 years old and married with two children. With one child still in school, Rosie works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell in her general store. She has been in this business for 29 years and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, snack foods, candies, biscuits, noodles, detergent soap, etc. 

Rosie would like to build and expand her business to secure her family's future.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita is a 51-year-old married woman with six children, three of whom are still in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Clarita has a general store business in the Philippines, and has requested a PHP 11,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store. She has been in this business for 3 years. 

In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Flormay

texts.en:
Flormay is a 38-year-old married woman with two children, who are both in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Flormay has a buy-and-sell nipa roofing business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more stock of nipa roofing to sell to her customers. She has been in this business for 15 years. 

In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more stock of nipa roofing to sell to her customers

loans.name: Emeline

texts.en:
Emeline is 35 years old and married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. 

Emeline runs a general store in the Philippines. She has been running the general store for 5 years and also earns an income from food vending.

Emeline requested a 15,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) to purchase additional items to sell in her general store. She has borrowed and repaid 5 loans from NWTF before this loan. 

Emeline aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 57 years old and married with three children.  

Elizabeth is in the agricultural business (pig fattening) in the Philippines. She has been in pig fattening for 10 years now, and has borrowed 5 times in the past from Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation to sustain it. Elizabeth requested a 12,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy feed and other supplies to raise her pigs.

Elizabeth would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and other supplies to raise her pigs.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna is a 42-year-old woman who is married with five children, three who are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Lorna has a business raising pigs in the Philippines. Lorna has been in this business for ten years. She requested a 13,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to purchase feed and other supplies to raise her pigs.

In the future, Lorna would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase feed and other supplies to raise her pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy cosmetic products, local soap and ice for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy clothing and potatoes for resale.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
La socia Margarita se sigue dedicando al negocio de tienda de abarrotes y restaurant, la socia por medio de estos negocios quiere sacar adelante a su familia,el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes y restaurant. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar arroz, azúcar, leche y galletas.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Margarita continues to work at her grocery shop and restaurant. It is through these businesses that she wants to help her family to move forward. Margarita’s dream is to expand her grocery shop and restaurant. She is applying for a loan in order to buy rice, sugar, milk and biscuits.

Margarita is happy with this loan and promises to make her repayments.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, milk and biscuits.

loans.name: Miriam Mercedes

texts.es: Desde la comodidad de su casa ubicada en un barrio del sur de Barranquilla, Miriam incitada por su hermana quien le propuso vender productos por intermedio de catálogos especializados, aceptó el reto al considerar que no intervendría con sus labores cotidianas en el hogar y sería una forma práctica de empezar su vida comercial. Ella ofrece todos los días a sus vecinos, amigos y familiares, vestuario y calzado para toda la familia, artículos para el hogar y productos de uso personal.  Actualmente está aplicando a su primer Credikiva con el que planea darle impulso a sus ventas y a la largo plazo cumplir su ideal de crecimiento. Con esta inversión responderá a la demanda de sus clientes quienes le han solicitado nuevo surtido de ropa; blusas, pantalones, suéteres y demás encargos. Miriam de 64 años es madre de una hija a quien seguirá apoyando en sus estudios y su gran desafío ha sido el rol de madre responsable de su hija sin contar con una figura paterna.
texts.en:
From the comfort of her home in a barrio south of Barranquilla, Miriam accepted her sister’s challenge: to sell catalogue products. Miriam agreed to this as it would not interfere with her daily chores, and would be a practical way to start a business.

Miriam sells clothes and footwear every day to her neighbours, friends and relatives. She also sells household items, and personal products.

Miriam is currently applying for her first Kiva loan in order to drive sales up and, in the long term, to achieve her goals of expanding the business. This investment will allow Miriam to respond to customers’ demands, who are calling for new clothing stock, such as blouses, trousers, and sweaters.

Miriam is 64 years old and a mother to one daughter whom she wants to continue supporting in her education. Miriam’s big challenge has been to be a responsible mother to her daughter without any support from the father.

loans.use: to buy new stock, including blouses, trousers, sweaters and more.

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
La socia Martha se dedica al negocio de librería y tambien la socia es abogado, la socia vende cuadernos, libros, lapiceros, borradores entre otros, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 9:00 p.m,la socia ya tiene 5 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de librería. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar cuadernos, libros, lapiceros y borradores.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Martha has a stationery shop and also works as a lawyer. Martha sells notebooks, books, pencils, erasers and other products. She works from 8am to 9pm and has five years’ experience at the business. It is going very well. 

Martha’s dream is to expand her stationery shop. She is applying for a loan in order to buy notebooks, books, pencils and erasers.

Martha is happy with this loan and promises to make her repayments.

loans.use: to buy notebooks, books, pencils and erasers.

loans.name: Ayida

texts.ru: Айида, 41 год, замужем, детей нет. У нее среднее образование. Она жизнерадостная и трудолюбивая. Около 13 лет назад начала заниматься животноводческой и полеводческой деятельностью, стартовав с 1,000 сом (KGS), Айида сумела развить свой бизнес с ежемесячным доходом в сумме до 15,000 сом (KGS). В ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеются: 2 коровы, 15 овец и 2 лошади. На 1,25 Га земли она выращивает ячмень, картофель для реализации. В целях расширения своего хозяйства Айида обратилась в Банк «Бай – Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 80,000 сом (KGS), на полученные денежные средства она намерена купить корову и нетель для увеличения поголовья. Айида планирует вложить доходы от бизнеса в дальнейшее увеличение своего хозяйства, хочет построить сараи для скота.
texts.en: Ayida is 41 years old, married, with no children.  She has a secondary education and is a happy and hardworking woman.  About 13 years ago, she got involved in animal husbandry and agriculture.  Having started with a capital of 1,000 som (KGS), she managed to develop her business and she currently makes a monthly income of up to 15,000 som (KGS).  She currently has two cows, 15 sheep and two horses on her farm.  She also grows barley and potatoes for resale on 1.25 hectares of land.  In order to further expand her activity, Ayida has turned to Bai Tushum and requested a loan of 80,000 som (KGS).  She intends to use her loan to buy one cow and one heifer in order to increase the size of her herd.  She is planning to use the earnings from her business to further increase her farming business.  She also wants to build a barn for her livestock.

loans.use: to buy one cow and one heifer in order to increase the size of her herd.

loans.name: Yulia

texts.en:
Hello lenders! This is Yulia, one of Ruma's agents. Yulia lives in South Bogor, a suburban area located in West Java, about two hours drive from Jakarta, the capital city of Indonesia. Yulia is happily married, and together with her husband, they have one cute daughter. 

By supporting this loan you will be providing extra working capital for Yulia's shop. This will allow Yulia to become an agent for Ruma’s layaway product designed for lower income communities called 'Mapan'. Mapan enables customers to save up, little by little, by depositing change at agents like Yulia and as their balance grows, it allows customers to make major asset purchases like housewares, appliances, and school supplies for their children.

As a Mapan agent, Yulia is responsible for processing deposits from customers into their Mapan accounts as well as receiving orders from customers who want to buy products listed in Ruma's Mapan catalog. When a customer orders, Yulia will submit the order via SMS and, within 5-10 days, the product will be delivered to the customer. With Mapan, Yulia believes that her community will be able to have access to higher quality products with better prices. 

As seen in the photo, Yulia is the one who is sitting and smiling. She is thankful for your kind and endless support.

loans.use: to provide additional working capital for shop thereby facilitating introduction of Ruma's new saving scheme for low income communities.

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en: Clementine is 50 years old. She is married with three children between the ages of 17 and 25. All of them go to school. She sells food stuffs and has been in business for eight years. With the loan, she would like to buy more beans, Irish potatoes, and cooking oil to sell. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption and to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more beans, Irish potatoes, and cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Joseline

texts.en: Joseline is 41 years old. She is married with four children between the ages of 9 and 20. All of them go to school. She sells clothes and has been in business for 18 years. With the loan, she would like to buy more clothes to sell. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children and to renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina works hard to support her family. Angelina is married and has a fish-vending business in the Philippines.

Angelina requested a PHP 19,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional boxes of fish to sell in her fish stall. Angelina has been in this business for 8 years now.

Angelina would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of fish to sell in her fish stall

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor is a 26-year-old young man who opened a small dairy farm. It all started with a little cow that was purchased for the family, and as time progressed the business expanded. At the moment Victor has 5 dairy cows and 12 three-month-old calves.
